title: China’s Rich List Shrinks, But the Cash Pile Grows
text:
Alibaba co-founder Jack Ma remained at the top of the Hurun list with a net worth of $39 billion, 2% higher than in 2018.

Text size

China’s roster of super-rich is shrinking, but those remaining on the list are swimming in more cash than ever, according to the latest China Rich List, published Thursday by the Hurun Report.

The consolidation of wealth into fewer hands was largely due to two factors, according to Rupert Hoogewerf, chief researcher of the report.

“Wealth is concentrating into the hands of those who are able to adapt to the digital economy,” he says. And companies with “strong business models, good teams, and [those] that can maintain a spirit of entrepreneurship are pushing forward relentlessly.”

While the number of super-rich—defined as those having personal wealth of at least $290 million—declined, their average net worth rose 10% from last year to $1.4 billion.

Last year’s wealthiest figure, Alibaba co-founder Jack Ma, remained at the top with a net worth of $39 billion, 2% higher than in 2018.

Pony Ma, of tech giant Tencent, was just behind, with $37 billion, up 8% from last year, pushing him ahead of property guru Xu Jiayin, whose wealth has dropped $13 billion over the last two years, when he was king of the list.

“The China Rich List is now looking like a two-horse race,” Hoogewerf says.

There was an exodus of names who didn’t make the $290 million cut this year. After a stunning 456 individuals fell off the list last year, another 266 dropped off this time around.

Hoogewerf says that “40% of the Hurun Rich List two years ago failed to make the cut this year, the biggest drop since records began 21 years ago. This works out at an average of one richlister dropping off each day for two years.”

The report showed that food had a good year and manufacturing had a bad one. Husband-and-wife pig farmers Qin Yinglin and Qian Ying tripled their wealth to $14 billion, putting them in the top 20. They sold a reported 5.8 million pigs in a market when pork prices skyrocketed due to an outbreak of African swine flu.

Other notable list-makers were 17 people who are currently in legal trouble—one of whom is already in prison, one who was charged with molesting a child, and one who’s been arrested for intentional homicide.

Perhaps the most impressive display of wealth-gain was from Colin Huang, 39, the founder of bargain e-commerce site Pinduoduo. In a mere four years after founding the company Huang is now worth $19 billion.

“Nobody in the world has ever made that much from a standing start,” Hoogewerf says.

Huang was one of 156 individuals under 40 to make the list this year.
description: New report shows more money is being held by fewer hands among the country’s ultra-wealthy
